It will be interesting to see what happens to the jet engines once budgets are introduced. Make them too expensive, and spaceplanes become obsolete in the career mode. Make them too cheap, and conventional rockets become obsolete.

I don't think that for the majority of players spaceplanes can ever be more useful than rockets, even with them being cheap. An SSTO that can get a Kerbal to orbit and back is something that most of the players would eventually be able to do. But a fully stock SSTO spaceplane with the same capabilities as a rocket, will be far too complex for most players. That combined with the tediousness of landing makes SSTO spaceplane a novelty for most, instead of something to rely on for most of your missions. Correctly balancing throwaway rockets (Soyuz, Apollo) vs. reusable rockets (SpaceX's Falcon rocket, orbital fuel depots and space tugs) will impact many more people's career modes.

I don't think that for the majority of players spaceplanes can ever be more useful than rockets, even with them being cheap. An SSTO that can get a Kerbal to orbit and back is something that most of the players would eventually be able to do. But a fully stock SSTO spaceplane with the same capabilities as a rocket, will be far too complex for most players. That combined with the tediousness of landing makes SSTO spaceplane a novelty for most, instead of something to rely on for most of your missions. Correctly balancing throwaway rockets (Soyuz, Apollo) vs. reusable rockets (SpaceX's Falcon rocket, orbital fuel depots and space tugs) will impact many more people's career modes.

The thing I'm worried about are jet-boosted rockets. Useful spaceplanes are hard enough to build, but if you remove the wings and add a few more engines, you get essentially the same performance in a much easier way. Even if you don't care about reusability, you can replace big rocket stages with small jet stages. That's possible even quite early in the career mode:

This rocket landed on Minmus and came back. Jet engines and intakes were the only 90-point parts used, while the rest was 45-point or less.

The root of the problem is that KSP jet engines are lighter and more powerful than real jet engines of similar size, while rocket engines are heavier and less powerful.

Who knows, maybe this will be the update that truly sells me on the career mode anyway.
